snippet: As the Ed O’Bannon case began on Monday, the N.C.A.A. settled another suit involving the use of college athletes’ likenesses in video games.
abstract: National Collegiate Athletic Assn reaches settlement to pay $20 million to current and former college athletes who sued over the use of their likenesses in video games; players who would most likely receive payments would be men’s basketball and football players who were on rosters of certain teams when the video games were sold; deal comes as higher-profile video game lawsuit, filed by form UCLA basketball star Ed O'Bannon, begins in federal court.

byline.original: By BEN STRAUSS and STEVE EDER
byline.contributor: Ben Strauss reported from Oakland, Calif., and Steve Eder from New York.

lead_paragraph: As the Ed O’Bannon case began on Monday, the N.C.A.A. settled another suit involving the use of college athletes’ likenesses in video games.

headline.main: N.C.A.A. Settles One Video Game Suit for $20 Million as a Second Begins
headline.print_headline: N.C.A.A. Settles One Video Game Suit for $20 Million as a Second Begins
